thread.title: Men are spending a third more than women on Valentine's Day
thread.title_full: Men are spending a third more than women on Valentine's Day

author: Rachel Clayton
title: Men are spending a third more than women on Valentine's Day
text:
Men are spending a third more than women on Valentine's Day RACHEL CLAYTON Last updated 17:32, February 14 2017 WARWICK SMITH/FAIRFAX NZ 
Men are spending up large on Valentine's Day, while women are happy to sit back and smell the roses. 
Kiwi men are the big spenders when it comes to showing their love, spending a third more on their partners than women on Valentines Day. 
Men spent on average $157, compared to $103 for women, according to Mastercard's latest consumer purchasing priorities survey. 
Wellington's Bloom Supply florist owner Chrissy Lawrence said Tuesday was great, but exhausting. 123RF 
Men are spending up large on Valentine's Day, while women are happy to sit back and smell the roses. 
"We've just put our last bunch out and it was crazy," she said. 
READ MORE: 
"We pretty much sold everything. Red roses were the most popular and we had orders coming through all day." 
Lawrence had two extra staff on to cover the busiest day of the year for florists. 
Bloom Supply was selling roses for $15 each, $75 for a bunch of six, and $145 for a dozen. 
Despite the rush Lawrence said her shop would open tomorrow as per usual. 
Sentimental spending using credit, debit and prepaid cards increased by 17 per cent over the past three years, with the number of items bought up by almost 60 per cent, according to Mastercard. Ad Feedback 
Unsurprisingly flowers were the most popular gift bought by men with almost half of Kiwi blokes planning to treat their partner to a bouquet. 
For women, a simple card was the most popular gift, followed by chocolate or lollies. Only one in 10 women bought flowers for their partner. 
"When it comes to Valentine's Day, Kiwis are sticking to traditional favourites including flowers and going out for a meal. The popularity of these gifts shows that Kiwis appreciate classic gestures," Mastercard New Zealand and Pacific Islands manager Peter Chisnall. 
Being a weekday the majority of people surveyed said they would rather spend time at home, while a third of New Zealanders would splash out and treat themselves to a meal out. 
The majority of Valentine's gifts were bought during the last minute dash on February 13. - Stuff
